history.content: It's really hard to predict, but they probably won't care so much if it's not in your major. If you're applying to CS and it's a CS course, I probably would continue to take it for a grade if it were me, especially if you took all of your classes P/NP in Spring 2020. If you're unsure, make an appointment with me or another advisor to talk it through.

children.subject: Best to contact the program you're potentially in directly as we can't speak to other programs and are undergrad advisors. That being said, if EECS 16A is not related to the program you would apply to, it's probably OK.
Does P/NP'ing eecs16a have an adverse effect on masters/grad programs?

My advice above still applies. Grad school is much more specific than undergrad. If you're applying to a CS/EECS master's or PhD program, you're applying to a specific area of EECS or CS, not the subjects as a whole. If you're planning on a CS MS or PhD program not related to EECS 16AB, it's probably fine, especially considering they are lower-division classes. Again, you could try to reach out to the specific programs.
What about PNP’ing EE16B for grad school? Is it ok to pnp a lower div, even if it’s in my major?

history.content: I'm not doing the best at home with online learning, and am thinking of PNP-ing one CS upper div to alleviate the stress. I was wondering how prospective masters/grad programs (also, 5th year masters) might perceive this if I'm PNPing a class not in the field I'm applying to/specializing in (Note, this class is not CS162 or CS170). Otherwise, I am considering using a late drop on either the mentioned course or another course.
history.subject: PNP Effect on Applications to Masters/Grad Programs
